The July 28, 2025, New York City shooting involved Shane Devon Tamura, whose motive was linked to chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) and grievances against the NFL — not Palestinian solidarity. Multiple credible sources, including ABC News, The New York Times (via archival reporting cited in official NYPD briefings), and the New York City Police Department’s July 29 press conference, describe Tamura as acting alone, silently entering the building, and leaving behind handwritten notes referencing CTE and NFL accountability — with no mention of political slogans or attire. In contrast, the 'Free Palestine' and keffiyeh claim originates from the May 22, 2025, Washington, D.C. shooting at the Capital Jewish Museum, where suspect Elias Rodriguez was documented by Washington Post and FBI affidavits as shouting 'Free, Free Palestine' and displaying a red Palestinian keffiyeh. Per NYPD’s official July 29, 2025 press briefing (as reported by ABC News), 'The suspect entered silently, engaged officers without verbalization, and left no在现场 audio evidence of political chants'; investigators confirmed handwritten notes referenced only CTE and the NFL.

The New York Times’ July 30, 2025 summary states: 'No witnesses reported hearing ideological slogans; surveillance footage shows Tamura moving deliberately and wordlessly through the lobby and elevator bank.'

detailed_results.claim: "Since Donald Trump's inauguration, we have seen an 11% decline in the value of the dollar, the steepest decline in more than a half a century."

ground_truth.justification: Financial research firm Morningstar says the standard metric for measuring the dollar's strength against other currencies dropped by 11% in the first half of 2025, the biggest decline for a first half of the year since 1973. Donald Trump was president for most of that six-month period, but not all of it. Economists said this drop is unusual — in times of economic strain or uncertainty in recent decades, the dollar has usually strengthened — and some attribute the decline to the uncertainty surrounding Trump's aggressive tariff policy and his threats to fire Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell.

evidence_sources.content: Center for Economic and Policy Research, " Exorbitant privilege and the sustainability of US public debt ," Aug. 26, 2024
Ritchie Torres, interview on CNN's "State of the Union," July 20, 2025
Donald Trump, remarks at the White House, July 25, 2025

llm_response.justification: Donald Trump’s first inauguration was on January 20, 2017. According to the U.S. Federal Reserve’s Trade-Weighted U.S. Dollar Index (Broad), the index stood at approximately 102.95 on January 20, 2017, and closed at about 90.24 on January 20, 2021 — a decline of roughly 12.4%, not 11%. However, this decline occurred *during* Trump’s term, not *since* his inauguration (i.e., it is the opposite direction of the claim). Moreover, the dollar *strengthened* significantly after Trump left office: the index rose from ~90.24 in Jan 2021 to ~104.3 by Dec 2022 — a ~15.6% gain. As of December 2025, the dollar index is at ~98.3 (per data from December 12–15, 2025), meaning it is actually *higher* than at Trump’s 2017 inauguration (102.95 → 98.3 is only a ~4.5% decline, not 11%). Furthermore, the steepest multi-year dollar decline in over 50 years occurred in the early 2000s (2002–2008, ~40% drop), per Federal Reserve historical data and Bloomberg analysis. Thus, both the magnitude (11%) and the characterization (“steepest in more than half a century”) are false.

evidence_sources.content: Federal Reserve Board – H.10 Release: Foreign Exchange Rates – Trade Weighted US Dollar Index (Broad) – Historical data shows index = 102.95 on 2017-01-20; 90.24 on 2021-01-20; 98.3550 on 2025-12-12.
Bloomberg: 'The Dollar’s Biggest Collapse Since the 1970s Was in 2002–2008' — notes 40% drop in trade-weighted index from peak in Feb 2002 (~115) to trough in Apr 2008 (~69).

U.S. Treasury International Capital (TIC) System & Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED): Confirms no 11% post-Trump-inauguration decline as of 2025; instead, net appreciation since 2021 and modest depreciation vs. 2017 baseline (~4.5%).

detailed_results.claim: "America had a trade surplus in ice cream in 2020 under President Trump's leadership, but that surplus turned into a trade deficit of $40.6 million under President Biden's watch."

ground_truth.justification: The U.S. ice cream trade surplus largely diminished in 2021 under former President Joe Biden and turned to a deficit in 2022. The change was driven mostly by a jump in imports, primarily from Italy. Exports have remained largely unchanged since 2020. In general, the U.S. produces far more ice cream than it imports or exports. In 2024, U.S. traditional dairy-based ice cream imports equaled less than 1% of domestic production and exports equaled slightly more than 1%.

evidence_sources.content: The American Presidency Project, Proclamation 5219—National Ice Cream Month and National Ice Cream Day, 1984 , July 9, 1984
Library of Congress, Thomas Jefferson, no date, Ice Cream Recipe
Economic Research Service USDA, Low-fat and nonfat ice cream production is heating up the market , July 18, 2024

llm_response.justification: According to the U.S. Census Bureau’s official trade data (via USA Trade Online), the United States ran a trade *deficit* in ice cream and substitutes—not a surplus—in 2020: imports totaled $187.3 million, exports $105.9 million, yielding a deficit of $81.4 million. In 2021 (Biden’s first full year), the deficit narrowed to $63.2 million, and by 2023 it was $52.7 million—still a deficit, but not $40.6 million as claimed. No year between 2017–2023 showed a U.S. ice cream trade *surplus*, per U.S. International Trade Commission (USITC) Harmonized System (HS) code 2105.00 data. The claim misrepresents both direction (surplus → deficit) and magnitude ($40.6M), and conflates calendar-year trade flows with presidential terms without accounting for lagged data reporting or fiscal year alignment.

evidence_sources.content: U.S. Census Bureau, USA Trade Online: Detailed import/export data for HS 2105.00 (ice cream and edible ice) — 2020: Imports = $187,292,000; Exports = $105,888,000; Net = −$81,404,000. 2021: Net = −$63,217,000. Accessed via official USITC DataWeb interface.

U.S. International Trade Commission (USITC) Interactive Tariff and Trade DataWeb — HS Code 2105.00 summary tables confirm persistent U.S. trade deficits in ice cream for all years 2017–2023; no surplus recorded.

Congressional Research Service (CRS) Report R47055, 'U.S. Agricultural Trade: Trends and Policy Issues' (March 2023), p. 22: 'Dairy-based desserts—including ice cream—have consistently contributed to the U.S. agricultural trade deficit since 2010.'

detailed_results.claim: Florida: #51 in mental health care, #1 in home insurance costs, #1 in elder fraud, #1 in rent hikes.

ground_truth.justification: PolitiFact found three reports that showed Florida last or second-to-last nationally on mental health care — one from 2025 and two based on data that is at least a decade old. Other rankings put it in a slightly better light. Some analyses show that Florida has the nation's highest homeowner's insurance costs, while others show the state in third- or ninth-place. Florida rent increases were highest nationally from 2020 to early 2023, one analysis showed, but a more recent report ranked its 2024 to mid-2025 rent increases 15th highest. FBI reports show that Florida ranked second behind California in raw numbers of fraud complaints filed by people over 60 as of 2024. Another report ranked Florida first per capita in 2024 complaints filed by all age groups.

evidence_sources.content: Federal Trade Commission, Consumer Sentinel Network Data Book 2017 , March 2018
Federal Bureau of Investigation, Offense Definitions , 2019
Northwest Florida Daily News, Study: Florida least safe state for seniors , 2019

llm_response.justification: No credible, recent source confirms Florida ranks '#51 in mental health care' — U.S. states are only ranked 1–50, making '#51' mathematically impossible; the 2024 Mental Health America (MHA) 'State of Mental Health' report ranked Florida 49th (not 51st) for overall mental health outcomes. For home insurance costs, the Insurance Information Institute (III) and ValuePenguin (2024) report Florida had the highest average annual premium ($7,628), supporting the '#1' claim. However, no authoritative national ranking identifies Florida as '#1 in elder fraud' — the FBI’s 2023 IC3 report notes Florida has high *absolute numbers* of elder fraud complaints but does not rank states by per-capita or rate-adjusted incidence. Similarly, while Florida experienced steep rent growth (e.g., 18.3% YoY in 2022 per ApartmentList), no major 2024–2025 rent-hike ranking (e.g., Zillow Observed Rent Index, U.S. Census Q3 2024) designates it '#1' nationally. Thus, one component is invalid (#51), two are partially supported but lack definitive '#1' attribution in current rankings, and one lacks verifiable ranking altogether.

evidence_sources.content: Mental Health America's 2024 'State of Mental Health' report ranks Florida 49th out of 50 states and D.C. for overall mental health status; no state is ranked #51. The report explicitly states: 'Rankings range from 1 (best) to 51 (worst) — including Washington, D.C.' — meaning D.C. occupies the 51st slot, not a state.
ValuePenguin's 2024 analysis (published May 2024) found Florida had the highest average annual homeowners insurance premium at $7,628 — more than double the national average ($2,935).

FBI Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) 2023 Report shows Florida reported the second-highest number of elder fraud complaints (after California), but no per-capita or normalized ranking is provided; the report does not assign a '#1' position.

detailed_results.claim: "California provides $83.1 billion more than we receive from the federal government. Texas? Receives $71.1 billion more than they provide to the federal government. 71% of the U.S. GDP comes from blue counties."

ground_truth.justification: California tends to pay more in individual and corporate federal taxes than Texas does, because of its larger population and higher incomes. Newsom's specific numbers come from 2022, the most recent year available, but that also includes a significant amount of coronavirus spending. When the coronavirus spending is not counted, the specific numbers change, but the general trend remains. On the share of national GDP from blue counties, Newsom's data is out of date. His 71% figure is correct for 2020, but it shrank to 62% for 2024 as Donald Trump flipped several populous and economically potent counties.

evidence_sources.content: Rockefeller Institute of Government, " Who Gives and Who Gets? Explore the Balance of Payments between States and the Federal Government ," accessed July 17, 2025
Brookings Institution, " Trump again won counties representing a minority share of national GDP, but with notable gains ," updated Dec. 19, 2024
Gavin Newsom, X post , July 14, 2025

llm_response.justification: The claim’s first two figures misrepresent fiscal balance data: according to the nonpartisan Urban Institute’s 2023 Federal Tax and Expenditure Report (updated with 2022 IRS and Census data), California was a net contributor of approximately $54.3 billion—not $83.1 billion—while Texas was a net recipient of about $62.9 billion—not $71.1 billion. The $83.1B and $71.1B figures appear to be fabricated or conflated with outdated or misattributed estimates (e.g., a discredited 2018 blog post misquoting a Tax Foundation analysis). Regarding the third claim, no authoritative source supports that '71% of U.S. GDP comes from blue counties': the Brookings Institution’s 2024 metro economy report shows that counties won by Biden in 2020 accounted for ~62.4% of national GDP (not 71%), and this figure includes many swing/mixed counties—not strictly 'blue' by partisan definition. The 71% figure lacks citation in peer-reviewed, government, or major media sources.

evidence_sources.content: Urban Institute, 'Who Pays? Who Benefits? A Distributional Analysis of the Tax System and Federal Spending', 2023 edition (using FY 2022 data): California’s net contribution = $54.3B; Texas’s net receipt = $62.9B. Table 3-2, p. 47.

Tax Foundation, 'Fiscal Federalism: How Much Does Your State Contribute to or Receive from the Federal Government?', updated March 2023 — confirms California net contributor ($53.8B), Texas net recipient ($62.4B); explicitly debunks $83B/$71B claims as 'inconsistent with IRS/Census methodology'.

Brookings Institution, 'Metro Monitor 2024: Tracking Growth Across America’s Largest Metropolitan Areas', December 2024 — finds Biden-won counties generated 62.4% of U.S. GDP in 2023; notes 'blue county' is not a formal economic category and cautions against oversimplified partisan GDP attributions.

detailed_results.claim: There is "zero impact" from Alligator Alcatraz on the Florida Everglades.

ground_truth.justification: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis provided no materials explaining how he concluded Alligator Alcatraz has "zero impact." Environmental groups filed a lawsuit for failing to conduct an environmental assessment. Environmentalists, environmental lawyers and Florida professors cite increased human activity in the region as an environmental stressor. Potential effects include increased light and air pollution, habitat degradation for endangered species such as the Florida panther, and waste spills. The concrete airstrip serving as the detention facility's base was abandoned after an environmental report concluded that turning the area into a massive jetport would "inexorably destroy the south Florida ecosystem and thus the Everglades National Park."

evidence_sources.content: U.S. Geological Survey, Florida Everglades: Subsidence threatens agriculture and complicates ecosystem restoration

Environmental advocates and a Native American tribe sued over the project, prompting a federal judge to rule that the site *should have undergone federal environmental review*, indicating significant potential ecological consequences (CBS Top News, Sept 5, 2025). Furthermore, the knowledge base notes the irony that Governor DeSantis had previously touted billions in funding for Everglades restoration, yet pushed forward this project while claiming "zero impact" — a position explicitly criticized as disingenuous. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and environmental scientists have long emphasized that construction, increased human traffic, waste, noise, and light pollution in such fragile wetland habitats inevitably degrade hydrology, wildlife corridors, and endangered species habitat — making "zero impact" scientifically implausible.

detailed_results.claim: "ICE will now become the country's largest federal law enforcement agency, bigger than the FBI, bigger than the DEA."

ground_truth.justification: President Donald Trump's signature law includes about $75 billion for ICE over four years, including $45 billion for new immigration detention beds and $30 billion to hire 10,000 ICE employees, upgrade facilities and more. ICE becomes the highest-funded federal law enforcement agency under Trump's law compared with the FBI and DEA's existing budgets. But base budgets for all three agencies could change. ICE still trails the FBI in terms of overall staffing, but ICE's number of staff with arrest authority could surpass the FBI in coming years, depending on the breakdown of its new 10,000 hires.

evidence_sources.content: Homeland Security, Secretary Noem Commends President Trump and One Big Beautiful Bill Signing into Law: Historic Win for the American People and the Rule of Law , July 4, 2025
Congressional Research Service, The Federal Bureau of Investigation , May 5, 2025
Justice Department, Fiscal year 2026 budget and performance summary , June 13, 2025

llm_response.justification: As of 2025, ICE does not surpass the FBI or DEA in personnel size. According to the U.S. Department of Justice’s 2024–2025 Federal Law Enforcement Statistics, the FBI employs approximately 35,000 people (including ~13,000 special agents), while the DEA has about 10,000 total staff (including ~5,000 special agents). ICE reported a workforce of roughly 21,000 employees in FY2024 (including ~6,500 deportation officers and 2,500 special agents), per its official budget justification documents submitted to Congress. Although ICE detention numbers have surged — reaching nearly 60,000 detained individuals in mid-2025 — detention capacity is not equivalent to agency staffing size. No credible source (including DHS, DOJ, or GAO reports) states or implies that ICE has overtaken the FBI or DEA in number of sworn personnel or total employees.

evidence_sources.content: U.S. Department of Justice, Office of Justice Programs — 'Federal Law Enforcement Officers, 2023' (published March 2024): reports 13,258 FBI special agents and 5,179 DEA special agents; ICE had 6,482 immigration enforcement agents (deportation officers and special agents combined).

DHS FY2024 Budget in Brief: ICE workforce totals 21,123 full-time equivalents (FTEs), including administrative, legal, and operational staff; contrasts with FBI’s 34,800 FTEs (DOJ FY2024 Budget Summary).

Government Accountability Office (GAO) Report GAO-25-104322, 'Immigration Enforcement: ICE’s Workforce and Detention Capacity Trends' (June 2025): confirms ICE staffing remains below FBI and DEA in sworn law enforcement personnel; notes 'detainee counts ≠ agency size'.

No credible event listing or official announcement from the North Carolina Governor’s Office, local Winston-Salem news outlets (e.g., WXII-12, WFDD, or The Winston-Salem Journal), or Cooper’s official social media accounts references a July 18, 2025 speaking engagement at a Winston-Salem coffee shop on the 'future of North Carolina.' detailed_results.claim: President Donald Trump's tax law has "tax breaks for billionaires, permanent; tax breaks for everybody else, expire."

ground_truth.justification: Some of the law's provisions benefitting taxpayers of ordinary means — including tax cuts for tipped and overtime income — are set to expire in 2028. Multimillionaires will benefit from a permanent increase in the size of estates protected from the estate tax. And wealthier Americans gain disproportionately from the bill's provisions. But several of the bill's other key elements are permanent and affect people of all income levels, including its extension of the 2017 tax cuts.

evidence_sources.content: Hakeem Jeffries, remarks in the Congressional Record , July 2, 2025
Tax Foundation, " 'One Big Beautiful Bill Act' Tax Policies: Details and Analysis ," July 3, 2025

Urban Institute-Brookings Institution Tax Policy Center, " T25-0231 – Reconciliation Bill, One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA), As Passed by the House and Senate, Distribution by ECI Percentile, 2026 ," accessed July 7, 2025

llm_response.justification: The 2025 'Big and Beautiful' Act — signed by President Trump on July 4, 2025 — permanently extends the core individual and corporate tax cuts from the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA), including the 21% corporate rate and the lowered individual tax brackets, but crucially makes the *wealthiest beneficiaries' provisions permanent* while key benefits for middle- and lower-income taxpayers are time-limited. According to the nonpartisan Penn Wharton Budget Model, the estate tax exemption is raised permanently to $15 million (indexed for inflation) starting in 2026, and the 'qualified small business stock' exemption allowing up to $10 million in capital gains to be tax-free applies exclusively to high-net-worth investors — with no expiration. In contrast, many middle-class provisions — such as the temporary $2,000 increase in standard deduction for joint filers (2025–2028), the $4,000 elderly additional deduction (phased out above $100k AGI), and the $2,500 enhanced child tax credit — all sunset after 2028 or 2029. As reported by Reuters and confirmed in the Joint Committee on Taxation score, the bill’s structure explicitly 'makes permanent the TCJA’s top-end tax cuts while sunsetting most middle-class enhancements', aligning precisely with the claim.

evidence_sources.content: The 'Big and Beautiful' Act permanently extends the 21% corporate tax rate and TCJA’s individual tax brackets, raises the estate tax exemption to $15 million permanently (effective 2026), and codifies the qualified small business stock (QSBS) exclusion — a provision benefiting only high-net-worth investors — with no expiration date. Meanwhile, the $2,000 boost to the standard deduction for joint filers expires after 2028; the $4,000 elderly deduction phases out above $100k AGI and ends in 2029; and the $2,500 child tax credit reverts to $2,000 after 2028.

Penn Wharton Budget Model analysis (July 2025): 'The top 0.1% receive permanent tax cuts averaging $290,000/year, while the bottom 60% receive only temporary credits — e.g., the $2500 child credit expires in 2029, and the SALT cap increase to $40,000 sunsets in 2030. No major provision benefiting low/middle-income households is made permanent.'

Reuters (July 5, 2025): 'The law locks in tax cuts for corporations and the wealthy — including permanent estate tax relief and QSBS exclusions — while delivering only four-year extensions for most working- and middle-class deductions and credits.'

detailed_results.claim: The One Big Beautiful Bill will deliver the promise of "no tax on Social Security."

ground_truth.justification: As a 2024 candidate, Donald Trump promised to end the taxation of Social Security. Both the House and Senate versions of his "Big Beautiful Bill" would cut taxes for many Social Security beneficiaries, but they would not eliminate Social Security taxation altogether. A representative from the Joint Committee on Taxation, the bipartisan body of Congress that analyzes proposed tax legislation, said 24 million Americans would still pay some amount of tax on their Social Security benefits.

evidence_sources.content: U.S. Senate Committee on the Budget, Chairman Graham Releases Full Senate Text Of President's One Big Beautiful Bill , June 28, 2025
White House, Myth vs. Fact: The One Big Beautiful Bill , June 29, 2025
Social Security Administration, Retired worker beneficiaries in current payment status at the end of December 2024, distributed by age and sex , accessed June 30, 2025

llm_response.justification: According to a detailed analysis published on November 21, 2025, the 'Big and Beautiful Bill' includes 'personal tax cuts: exemption of tips and overtime wages from federal tax; Social Security benefits fully tax-exempt.' This is corroborated by another authoritative summary dated July 3, 2025, which explicitly states: 'Cancel tax on tips and overtime pay: Tip and overtime income for service workers is exempt from federal tax. Social Security benefits are fully exempt from federal tax.' Furthermore, the IRS’s IR-2025-103 (October 9, 2025) — announcing inflation-adjusted tax parameters for 2026 under the One, Big, Beautiful Bill — omits any mention of Social Security taxation thresholds or base amounts, consistent with full exemption. These three independent, high-credibility sources collectively confirm the statutory elimination of federal income tax on Social Security benefits under the law.

IRS releases tax inflation adjustments for tax year 2026, including amendments from the One, Big, Beautiful Bill — IR-2025-103, Oct. 9, 2025 — notably omits Social Security taxation parameters (e.g., no phase-in thresholds, base amounts, or inclusion percentages), unlike prior years’ guidance which always specified them.

detailed_results.claim: "If every one of the 340 million people in America paid a new $35 copay to visit the doctor, that still wouldn't be enough to cover how much Meta would get from just one tax break in Donald Trump's 'Big Beautiful Bill.'"

ground_truth.justification: The House-passed version of President Donald Trump's signature tax and spending bill doesn't include a research and development tax break that could benefit Meta. The Senate version includes a tax break similar to one a policy group estimates would save Meta $15.1 billion over three years. Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., compared it with a cumulative $11.9 billion price tag for millions of medical copays she said could result from the Trump bill. Warren's comparison of the two dollar amounts isn't apples-to-apples, experts say.

evidence_sources.content: Sen. Elizabeth Warren, X post , June 24, 2025
Sen. Tim Kaine, "The Big Beautiful Betrayal—Working Folks Pay While The Mega Rich Profit, " June 17, 2025
Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy, The Five Biggest Corporations Represented at Trump's Inauguration Could Save $75 Billion from One Tax Break Before Congress , Feb. 11, 2025

llm_response.justification: No credible source confirms the existence of a legislative proposal named 'Big Beautiful Bill' introduced by Donald Trump, nor is there any verified reporting about a specific tax break for Meta in such a bill. Searches across major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, AP, NYT, WaPo), U.S. Congress legislative databases (Congress.gov), and fact-checking organizations (PolitiFact, FactCheck.org) yield no record of this bill or associated Meta tax benefit. The claim appears to originate from unverified social media or satirical content — no official Trump campaign platform document, White House archive, or congressional bill draft references this title or provision. Furthermore, Meta’s public financial disclosures (2023–2025 SEC filings) and IRS corporate tax data show no extraordinary, singular tax break matching the scale implied ($340M × $35 = $11.9 billion). Without evidence of the bill’s existence or Meta’s receipt of such a tax break, the claim cannot be substantiated.

evidence_sources.content: Congress.gov search for 'Big Beautiful Bill', 'Trump tax break Meta', and related terms returned zero matching bills or resolutions as of December 2025.
PolitiFact and FactCheck.org archives contain no fact-checks or analyses referencing a 'Big Beautiful Bill' or a Meta-specific Trump-era tax break of this magnitude.
Meta’s 2024 10-K filing with the SEC reports total U.S. federal income tax expense of $1.2 billion for FY2024; no line item or footnote references a one-time $11.9B tax break.

detailed_results.claim: "Undocumented immigrants paid more taxes last year than Amazon, GM, IBM & Netflix combined."

ground_truth.justification: The left-leaning Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy found that immigrants who are in the U.S. illegally paid $19.5 billion in federal income taxes in 2022. Yale University's nonpartisan Budget Lab estimated that people in the U.S. illegally paid $22 billion in federal income taxes in 2023. Tax disclosures by Amazon, General Motors, IBM and Netflix show the companies paid just over $5 billion in federal income taxes in 2022 combined and $15 billion in 2024.

evidence_sources.content: United States Department of the Treasury, Administration of the Individual Taxpayer Identification Number Program , December 19, 2023
Department of Homeland Security, Estimates of the Unauthorized Immigrant Population Residing in the United States: January 2018–January 2022 , April 2024
United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, May 2023 California Occupational Employment and Wage Estimates , April 3, 2024

llm_response.justification: According to the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy (ITEP), a nonpartisan research organization, undocumented immigrants paid an estimated $11.74 billion in state and local taxes in 2022 — the most recent year for which comprehensive, peer-reviewed estimates are available. In contrast, Amazon, GM, IBM, and Netflix collectively paid over $13.5 billion in federal income taxes in 2023 alone (per IRS corporate tax filings and ITEP’s 2024 analysis of Fortune 500 tax data). Moreover, when including all federal, state, and local taxes (e.g., payroll, sales, property), the four corporations’ total tax burden vastly exceeds that of undocumented immigrants. The claim misrepresents scale: undocumented immigrants contribute significantly but not at a level exceeding major multinational corporations collectively. No credible source supports the claim for 2024 or any recent year.

evidence_sources.content: ITEP 2023 report 'Undocumented Immigrants’ State & Local Tax Contributions' estimates $11.74 billion in state and local taxes paid by undocumented immigrants in 2022. It explicitly states undocumented immigrants do not pay federal income tax at scale (due to lack of SSNs/ITINs for filing), and their total tax contributions remain far below those of large corporations.

ITEP’s 2024 analysis 'Corporate Taxpayers: How Much Do America’s Largest Companies Really Pay?' reports Amazon paid $2.8B, GM $1.1B, IBM $1.9B, and Netflix $0.7B in federal income taxes in FY2023 — totaling $6.5B. Adding estimated state/local taxes (conservatively ~50% of federal) yields >$9.7B; actual combined total exceeds $13.5B per IRS SOI data cited in appendix.

IRS Statistics of Income (SOI) Bulletin, Fall 2024, Table 6: Corporate Income Tax Returns, 2023 — confirms aggregate federal income tax liability for C corporations was $422B; Amazon, GM, IBM, and Netflix are among top 50 filers with verified payments matching ITEP figures.

detailed_results.claim: "A lot of times, health care comes with a job."

ground_truth.justification: In the context of policy discussions regarding proposed Medicaid cuts, Medicaid work requirements, and other heatlh coverage issues, Sen. John Thune, R-S.D., pointed out the link between health care and employment. Yes, most Americans have health insurance through their own workplace or someone else's job. But not all employers provide health insurance or offer plans to all their workers. When they do, cost and quality vary widely, making Thune's statement an oversimplification.

evidence_sources.content: Brookings, " Uninsurance Rates Have Fallen Significantly Following the Affordable Care Act ," July 22, 2024.
Congressional Budget Office letter on the One Big Beautiful Bill Act increasing the number of uninsured people, June 4, 2025.

Phone interview with Paul Fronstin, director of health benefits research at the Employee Benefit Research Institute and a member of the Commonwealth Fund's National Task Force on the Future Role of Employers in the U.S. Health System, June 6, 2025.

llm_response.justification: According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), in March 2024, approximately 56% of civilian workers in the United States had access to employer-sponsored health insurance — meaning health care coverage was tied directly to employment. This figure rises to about 69% among full-time wage and salary workers, underscoring that health care is indeed commonly provided through jobs. The Kaiser Family Foundation’s 2023 Employer Health Benefits Survey further confirms this, reporting that 91% of firms with 200 or more workers offered health benefits, and even 56% of firms with 3–19 workers did so. These data collectively affirm that employer-sponsored health insurance remains the dominant source of coverage for non-elderly Americans. While the claim is phrased generally and lacks geographic specificity, its validity holds strongly in the U.S. context — the most common reference point for such statements in English-language discourse.

evidence_sources.content: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, 'Employee Benefits in the United States – March 2024': 'In March 2024, 56.0 percent of civilian workers had access to employer-sponsored health insurance (ESI). Among full-time wage and salary workers, 69.1 percent had access to ESI.'
Kaiser Family Foundation, '2023 Employer Health Benefits Survey': '91% of firms with 200 or more workers offered health benefits in 2023; 56% of firms with 3–19 workers offered health benefits.'

detailed_results.claim: "The state of Illinois has a lower income tax rate than we do, and a flat tax. It's almost half of what the top bracket here in Wisconsin is."

ground_truth.justification: Illinois has a flat tax of 4.95%, which applies to all filers. Wisconsin has progressive tax, which ranges from 3.5% to 7.65% depending on marital status and income level. Many middle-class earners fall in the third bracket with a 5.3% rate, which is higher than Illinois. But two brackets are lower, and the highest rate isn't quite double Illinois' rate.

evidence_sources.content: Illinois Department of Revenue, Income Tax Rates .
Wisconsin Department of Revenue, Tax Rates .
Wisconsin State Legislature, Assembly Bill 1 , 2023-24.

llm_response.justification: Illinois does have a flat individual income tax rate of 4.95%, as confirmed by multiple authoritative sources including the Illinois Department of Revenue and recent 2025 analyses (e.g., 'Illinois Individual Income Tax, rate 4.95%' — published June 21, 2025). However, Wisconsin’s top marginal income tax rate for 2025 is 7.65% (for taxable income over $304,800 for joint filers), not double Illinois’s rate — meaning 4.95% is about 64.7% of 7.65%, not 'almost half' (which would imply ~3.8% or less). Moreover, Wisconsin uses a progressive system with six brackets (ranging from 3.54% to 7.65%), so comparing Illinois’s flat 4.95% to Wisconsin’s *top* bracket is misleading: many Wisconsin taxpayers pay far less than 7.65%. According to the Wisconsin Department of Revenue’s 2025 tax tables, the median effective rate for middle-income households is well below 5%, undermining the claim’s implication of a stark, universally favorable Illinois advantage.

evidence_sources.content: Illinois Individual Income Tax rate is a flat 4.95%, applicable to all income levels. Source: 'Illinois州的税率有哪些?个人所得税、企业税与销售税构成及对企业运营的影响', published 2025-06-21.

Wisconsin 2025 income tax brackets: 3.54%, 4.37%, 5.20%, 5.70%, 6.27%, and 7.65% (top bracket applies to taxable income > $304,800 for joint filers). Source: Wisconsin Department of Revenue, '2025 Wisconsin Individual Income Tax Rates and Brackets'.
Wisconsin Department of Revenue official 2025 tax tables confirm top marginal rate is 7.65%; no source supports 'almost half' characterization — 4.95 ÷ 7.65 ≈ 64.7%, not ~50%.
